{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3468299,"name":"Eliot Dunn","username":"Eliot","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eliot/{size}/207280_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-04T04:30:21.882Z","cooked":"

Thin_2_Stage_Example_82547×3296 1.51 MB

Well, that was a long title.

Two months ago I had an idea (and a challenge) to make a COTS-compatible belt in-tube elevator.

{71BCC078-BD41-4D3C-9826-332B1D31D097}756×98 14.7 KB

The main constraint was that teams had to be able to manufacture a continuous elevator with no tube CNC and just a band saw and a vendor kit.

My first iteration revolved around giant billet bearing blocks, which wasn’t workable. (Thank you to @thevedantin for trying to make it workable)

Bearing Block(1)3296×2547 1010 KB

Bearing Blocks

When REV came out with their new clamping bearing block, I decided to make a V2 centered around that design. The bearing block is built with two 3/16" plates, REV clamping bearing blocks, and a 3dp crush block connecting them.

Thin_2_Stage_Example_113296×2547 1.55 MB

Thin_2_Stage_Example_103296×2547 1.43 MB

The idler stackup is stolen from @Nick_Coussens. It uses a 19mm od tube as the idler body, with washers on the outside. I elected to go this route rather than use printed pulleys to ensure that they would never fail.

Bearing Block(2)3296×2547 1.38 MB

Gearbox

The gearbox is powered by MAXPlanetaries and supports 24-36t pulleys, allowing for a large range of reductions (in inches per revolution):

  • 5:1: 1.88-2.83
  • 9:1: 1.04-1.57
  • 12:1: 0.78-1.18

This ranges from the gearing 8096 used in their 2023 elevator to climb, to the gearing 4414 used in their 2023 elevator to score suuuper fast.

Thin_2_Stage_Example_93296×2547 2.09 MB

The gearbox is built to support elevator widths between 13" and infinity inches. All you need to do is change the length of the tube connecting it to the idler.

Idler

The redirect idlers go into the tube for strength.

Thin_2_Stage_Example_123296×2547 1.6 MB

Tensioning

The elevator is tensioned on the top of the carriage with a WCP cam. You would need to drill out some of the holes at the top of this tube for clearance for the bolts.

Thin 2 Stage Example(1)3296×2547 1.59 MB

The belt is secured on the down line by a simple plate. Use a different configuration depending on the width of the carriage.

Thin 2 Stage Example(2)3296×2547 1.89 MB

Belt Holder(1)3296×2547 883 KB

For the down belt, I had to cut a 1.25" hole out with a hole saw.

Thin 2 Stage Example (14)3296×2547 1.24 MB

I wanted to also have a configurable 3 stage elevator in this document, but I didn’t have the time to make that. Everything needed for infinite stages is in the document, however. In the future, I want to make a new iteration with 0.25" stage gaps and better bearing overlap.

CAD

Thank you to @hanoop, @thevedantin, and @Nick_Coussens (and a lot of other people) for giving me such good feedback on this design!

Thin_2_Stage_Example_72547×3296 1.77 MB

I was using this belt:

WestCoast Products

Elevator Components

Elevators can be more effective at lifting objects than arms because they don’t move the object further away from the robot while lifting. The tradeoff in performance comes with complexity, and often this has kept many teams from making elevator...

Price: USD 49.99

image1065×101 11.5 KB

Of course, this wasn’t ever built.

Fantastic work! We had a similar elevator in our 2024 bot, and the change of the in-carriage holder plates both being on the top and bottom is a great change compared to our design, which had that as a notable shortcoming

image754×661 150 KB

the question of this image, how do you keep the nautili tight on the vertical parts? Very carefully

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":38,"updated_at":"2025-01-06T00:15:27.870Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":11,"reads":1102,"readers_count":1101,"score":350.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":478210,"topic_slug":"belted-continous-in-tube-no-tube-manufacturing-elevator","display_username":"Luke Maxwell","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54103,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming / Media mentor"},"post_url":"/t/belted-continous-in-tube-no-tube-manufacturing-elevator/478210/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482030,"name":"Andrew Pepmeier","username":"Pep3176","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pep3176/{size}/236589_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T14:29:00.398Z","cooked":"

This is very intriguing, seeing as for a lot of teams a belt-in-tube setup is beyond their manufacturing capabilites. Have you designed any 3-stage elevators that keep the belt-in-tube design? Could be useful this season to reach height. Very impressive design!

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":38,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T14:29:00.398Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":962,"readers_count":961,"score":222.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":478210,"topic_slug":"belted-continous-in-tube-no-tube-manufacturing-elevator","display_username":"Andrew Pepmeier","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68395,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/belted-continous-in-tube-no-tube-manufacturing-elevator/478210/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482046,"name":"Eliot Dunn","username":"Eliot","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eliot/{size}/207280_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T14:37:47.786Z","cooked":"

These bearing blocks can very easily be put in more tubes to reach another stage. All you have to do is copy the design of the first moving stage again. You also might want to change the bottom belt holder to the other configuration.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":38,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T14:37:47.786Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":935,"readers_count":934,"score":186.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":478210,"topic_slug":"belted-continous-in-tube-no-tube-manufacturing-elevator","display_username":"Eliot Dunn","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":68395,"username":"Pep3176","name":"Andrew Pepmeier","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pep3176/{size}/236589_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52966,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"111 Alum"},"post_url":"/t/belted-continous-in-tube-no-tube-manufacturing-elevator/478210/9","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482076,"name":"Eliot Dunn","username":"Eliot","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eliot/{size}/207280_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T14:55:59.908Z","cooked":"

It looks like a few people are actually planning to build this elevator, which I was not expecting. I have a few notes for anyone planning to make this:

In tube plates

Tube tolerances aren’t exact, so the internal dimensions of them aren’t exact. REV lists theirs as 0.06", which works for these plates. Just know, if you have slightly oversized tubes you may need to file the plates down.

Tapping

A 2 stage elevator requires 48 tapped holes. That will probably take a lot of time. You can get fabworks or send cut send to do it for you, but that adds a ton of additional cost.

Idler Shaft

This shaft can either be 8mm or 5/16" in diameter, and should be cut down to 2".

Elevator blocks

This needs the REV elevator blocks (or a lot of facing operations on the WCP one). They are currently out of stock. REV’s website says that they should be in stock by the end of January.

Belt retention

If you’re using an elevator that isn’t the exact width of my example one, you should use this bottom belt holder, not the other configuration.

7e9ebc176e8cb6066e8f7a2f4d8150f74a42e2703296×2547 367 KB

I’ve never built this

While I think the mechanical design is sound, I have never built this in real life, and neither has anyone else. I haven’t had anyone find and point out mechanical problems to me, but that doesn’t mean that they aren’t there. If you’re building this, you might want to budget some time to fixing issues as they pop up. If you find any issues, PLEASE tell me.

Hey I’m wondering how you intended to source the tubing for the idler… I’m designing something similar to what you have in terms of In-Tube. I am struggling to find tubing like that.

For this particular item, I agree it seems like 6063 would be fine. However in general it’s weaker than 6061-T6. You may have a more common alloy local to you that’s close to 6061 strength.

Thank you for this design! My team has just finished building a slightly modified version of this lift to use at our 3 off-season events this year, and it works great! We also took some inspiration from 8744, who added thin polycarb “rails” for the bearing blocks to prevent any stages from slipping off or coming loose.

Is that about 3.5 pounds of polycarb for the rails? I’m sure a comp bot would get a WHOLE lot of pocketing

Thanks! I am not sure on the exact weight of the polycarb, but it has already proven to be absolutely worth it. Definitely would add pocketing wherever possible for an in-season robot (although we are still well within weight limit, 5-10 lbs to spare after we re-attach our arm/intake).

How do the polycarb rails work? It seems they act as a spacer? or is that incorrect?

","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":38,"updated_at":"2025-05-12T18:10:10.104Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":15,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":588,"readers_count":587,"score":147.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":478210,"topic_slug":"belted-continous-in-tube-no-tube-manufacturing-elevator","display_username":"Elliot S","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":23110,"username":"iKlein4531","name":"Ian K","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/iklein4531/{size}/244958_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50070,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Probably CADing | 2877 LigerBots Alum-Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/belted-continous-in-tube-no-tube-manufacturing-elevator/478210/18","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3622121,"name":"Ian K","username":"iKlein4531","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/iklein4531/{size}/244958_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-12T18:26:16.019Z","cooked":"

They help in maintaining the proper spacing between stages in the lift by physically not allowing the bearings to horizontally move off of the aluminum stage they roll on - small spacers were added to the REV bearing blocks to accommodate the extra distance the bearings needed to reach and so that the plates can fit! This is the big part we got from 8744 after a couple of discussions with them at our competitions.
